Actually, I would say the terrorists attack any and all countries that exercise political policies that are contrary to their beliefs. The 9/11 attacks against the US illustrated that they are perfectly willing to confront the "mightiest" nation in the world. The countries that seem to avoid terrorism are the ones that "mind their own business". I know that statement will strike a nerve with many, but down deep, I think everyone knows it's true.

I see two different areas of turmoil. One is the Israel/US/Coalition based on direct foreign intervention in Mideast affairs, the other in individual countries such as the Philippines, Thailand and former USSR States where Muslim populations seek government recognition and representation as an ethnic group. The former is supported by US money and materials to support special interest groups while individual conflicts seem to remain internal political issues. 
 
 Those countries that mind their own business do seem untouched by the violence experienced by coalition members, but let's remember that all coalition members are virtually mercenaries recruited by the US using military aid, direct financial aid and trade loan guarantees. Under US criminal law, those involved would be defined as contract killers. I'd think Islamic extremists view it in a similar manner. 
 
 Supporters of the coalition who rationalize coalition support as being motivated by political ideology in support of democracy need to question those motivations. Money talks and I find it difficult to imagine any coalition members in Iraq if they were paying for it out of their own pocket. $66 million plus all Iraq incurred expenses for Poland seems ironic when we're unable to fund many of our domestic programs without using debt.
